awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Effects of wildfires on lake productivity and oxygen deficits in the western U.S.
awd_abstract_narration:
Extreme wildfires now occur with increasing regularity in western North America and other parts of the world. These wildfires generate large plumes of smoke and ash that can travel thousands of miles and persist for weeks or longer in the atmosphere. These “smoke storms” block sunlight and deposit ash on surfaces. Lakes and ponds are affected by the reduced light and ash inputs from wildfires, but much about these potential impacts is unknown. Light and nutrients are both important factors that regulate the growth of plants and algae in aquatic ecosystems. Rates of primary production from plants and algae in turn determine how much food becomes available for other organisms, such as fish, and can affect many aspects of water quality. Thus, understanding how and why aquatic primary production is responding to wildfires is a critical research objective. This project will help develop a predictive understanding of how aquatic ecosystems respond to wildfire, serving the 29 National Forests, 14 National Parks, and numerous lands managed by the states of California and Oregon. The project will provide Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) training to undergraduate, graduate students, and post-doctoral scholars. Presentations of the results will be given to scientists, managers, and the general public through professional conferences and public lecture series hosted by the Tahoe Environmental Research Center, and through other state and federal agencies. 

This project will disentangle the interactive effects of reduced solar radiation, elevated presence of smoke and increased atmospheric deposition of particulates and ash on the ecosystem metabolism and dissolved oxygen dynamics of small lakes. The project will make use of a network of lakes in California and Oregon along ecologically relevant gradients. Satellite remote sensing data will be compiled, in combination with ground-based air quality monitoring data to quantify smoke and particulate deposition dynamics. Several ecosystem response variables have been measured prior to the 2020 wildfire season and this project will add important short-term knowledge about fire impacts from days to months. New measurements and instrumentation will be added to ongoing measurements from 23 aquatic ecosystems. By studying basic ecosystem functioning in lakes of varying size, water clarity, and productivity, the project will ascertain the effects of smoke and ash from wildfires. Ultimately, data from this project will help characterize the spatial linkages of smoke and ash deposition from large regional wildfires. The functioning of lakes will be determined through measurements of gross primary production, ecosystem respiration, and ecosystem oxygen dynamics, including cross-seasonal linkages between autumn and winter. This will lead to a mechanistic understanding of how interactions among drivers of ecosystem function affected by wildfires at landscape scales affect responses in individual aquatic ecosystems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Extreme wildfires now occur with increasing regularity in many parts of the world. These wildfires generate large plumes of smoke and ash that can travel thousands of miles and persist for weeks or longer in the atmosphere. The consequences of these “smoke storms” on aquatic systems is not well understood, in part because it is difficult to predict when and where fires will occur and document impacts. We collected dissolved oxygen and water temperature data from twenty different aquatic systems in California between 2018 and 2021 to evaluate the extent to which smoke from wildfires altered ecosystem metabolic rates. We expected smoke to reduce rates of primary production in highly productive systems, where light might already be limiting. In contrast, we expected primary production in clear water systems to either remain unaffected or to be enhanced slightly, with smoke reducing photoinhibition or harmful UV effects on primary producers.

 

While our analyses remain ongoing, our preliminary results highlight several important findings. First, although smoke caused water temperature to decline across all systems, the magnitude of the cooling was dependent on the morphometry of the aquatic system. Second, there was a high degree of variation in how the metabolic rates of systems responded to smoke. How a system responded was in part determined by ecosystem size and in part by the thickness of the smoke and duration of the smoke cover. Although variation in those factors made it difficult to generalize across systems, aquatic systems that experienced prolonged exposure to thick smoke responded more so than those with thin or intermittent smoke cover. In general, small, oligotrophic water bodies were the most responsive to smoke cover, rapidly cooling, increasing in dissolved oxygen, and showing clear shifts in ecosystem metabolism. In these systems, smoke reduced both rates of primary production and respiration, but the reduction in respiration was larger, which caused net ecosystem production to increase. Although the response to smoke in rates of primary production among eutrophic and mesotrophic systems were more variable, effects on respiration were generally small, which caused net ecosystem production to decline. Finally, the seasonal timing of fires was important, with the relative effect of smoke larger when fires occurred earlier in the summer, before lakes begin their seasonal cooling.

 

Several important outcomes associated with this project involve broadening scientific participation. The first was the development of a working group within the Global Lake Ecological Observatory Network that is focused on understanding the direct and indirect effects of wildfire on aquatic ecosystems. The formation of a working group has brought together the cross disciplinary expertise spanning physical, chemical, and biological limnology, remote sensing, and data science. Working group activities have focused on assessing the state of our scientific understanding through the review and synthesis of the scientific literature and the development of conceptual models of smoke effects. To facilitate further working group analyses, we have developed and are maintaining a growing database of temperature and oxygen data to inform analyses of smoke impacts on ecosystem function. A second substantive outcome supporting broadening scientific participation has been engagement between scientists and regional natural resource managers through the Tahoe Science Advisory Council, where an ongoing dialogue has helped communicate scientific results to managers, while identifying management priorities around direct and indirect effects of wildfire on aquatic systems for scientists. Given the scope and magnitude of wildfire effects, such direct engagement between scientists, managers, and policymakers is critical to setting research priorities, advancing scientific understanding, and ensuring the best available information steers policy.
